Q: Is there a stopwatch in Java? A:

com.google.common.base.Stopwatch

Use Stopwatch class from Google Guava.

An object that measures elapsed time in nanoseconds. It is useful to measure elapsed time using this class instead of direct calls to System.nanoTime() for a few reasons:

  • An alternate time source can be substituted, for testing or performance reasons.
  • As documented by nanoTime, the value returned has no absolute meaning, and can only be interpreted as relative to another timestamp returned by nanoTime at a different time. Stopwatch is a more effective abstraction because it exposes only these relative values, not the absolute ones.

Basic usage:

Stopwatch stopwatch = Stopwatch.createStarted();
doSomething();
stopwatch.stop(); // optional

Duration duration = stopwatch.elapsed();

log.info("time: " + stopwatch); // formatted string like "12.3 ms"

Q: What's the best way to get a live update of a laptops battery percentage and status via a C program? A:

Use your OS API. MS has GetSystemPowerStatus(). Linux has command line tools like acpi and upower. If there is no equivalent API in Linux, you could perhaps redirect output from these command line tools to a file, read the file and use the info in your program.
